option_a: A mechanism where a class acquires properties and methods from a parent class
option_b: A way to hide implementation details
option_e: A design pattern for creating objects
explanation: Inheritance is an OOP principle where a subclass (child) extends a superclass (parent) and inherits its fields and methods. In SPLAT: Statement is a parent class, and PrintStatement, Assignment, IfThenElse are subclasses that extend Statement. Use 'extends' keyword in Java.

option_a: The ability of objects to take multiple forms - same interface, different implementations
option_b: Creating multiple instances of a class
explanation: Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass. Example in SPLAT: All Statement subclasses can be stored in List<Statement>, and calling stmt.execute() invokes the appropriate subclass method (PrintStatement.execute(), Assignment.execute(), etc.). This is runtime polymorphism (dynamic dispatch).

question_text: What is the purpose of throwing exceptions in Java?
option_a: To handle error conditions and transfer control to exception handlers
explanation: Exceptions provide a way to handle errors gracefully. When an error occurs (e.g., invalid character in Lexer), we throw an exception (throw new LexException(...)) which unwinds the call stack until caught by a try-catch block. All SPLAT exceptions extend SplatException, which tracks line/column numbers.

question_text: What is the difference between List and Map in Java?
option_a: List: ordered collection by index; Map: key-value pairs
option_b: List: for primitives; Map: for objects
option_c: List: faster access; Map: slower access
option_d: List: fixed size; Map: dynamic size
explanation: List (like ArrayList) stores ordered elements accessed by index (0, 1, 2...). Map (like HashMap) stores key-value pairs accessed by key. In SPLAT: List<Token> stores tokens, Map<String, FunctionDecl> maps function names to declarations, Map<String, Value> maps variable names to values.

question_text: What is an abstract class in Java?
option_a: A class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods to be implemented by subclasses
option_b: A class that can only have static methods
option_d: A class that cannot have constructors
option_e: A final class that cannot be extended
explanation: Abstract classes: (1) Cannot be instantiated directly (can't do 'new Statement()'), (2) Can have abstract methods (no implementation) that subclasses must implement, (3) Can have concrete methods with implementation. In SPLAT: Statement, Expression, Declaration, ASTElement are abstract classes.

question_text: In the context of C data structures, when do you need malloc() and when do you need free()?
option_a: malloc() to allocate memory in constructor; free() to deallocate memory in destructor
option_b: malloc() for stack allocation; free() for heap allocation
option_c: malloc() for primitive types; free() for objects
option_e: malloc() and free() are not needed in C
explanation: In C, malloc() allocates memory on the heap (used in constructor/creation), and free() deallocates it (used in destructor/cleanup) to prevent memory leaks. In Java, you don't need malloc()/free() - the JVM handles memory allocation (new) and garbage collection automatically.

question_text: What does the 'instanceof' operator do in Java?
option_a: Checks if an object is an instance of a specific class or implements an interface
option_b: Creates a new instance of a class
option_d: Checks if a class extends another class
option_e: Determines the memory address of an object
explanation: instanceof tests whether an object is an instance of a specific type. Example from SPLAT: 'if (decl instanceof FunctionDecl)' checks if a Declaration is specifically a FunctionDecl. Returns true if the object is an instance of that class or any subclass.

question_text: What is a static method in Java?
option_a: A method that belongs to the class itself, not to instances - called without creating an object
option_b: A method that cannot be overridden
option_e: A method that cannot throw exceptions
explanation: Static methods belong to the class, not to individual objects. Called as ClassName.methodName(). Cannot access instance variables/methods (this doesn't exist in static context). Example: Value.makeInt(5) could be a static factory method that returns a new IntValue.

question_text: What is a constructor in Java?
option_a: A special method called when creating an object to initialize its state
option_c: A static method for building classes
option_d: A method that returns a class type
option_e: A final method that cannot be overridden
explanation: Constructors: (1) Same name as class, (2) No return type (not even void), (3) Called automatically with 'new', (4) Initialize object fields. Example: 'public Token(String lexeme, int line, int col)' is a constructor. If not defined, Java provides a default no-arg constructor.

question_text: What is the difference between public, private, and protected in Java?
option_a: public: accessible everywhere; private: only within class; protected: within class and subclasses
option_b: public: for methods; private: for fields; protected: for constructors
option_c: public: static members; private: instance members; protected: abstract members
option_d: They all mean the same thing
option_e: public: fast; private: slow; protected: medium speed
explanation: Access modifiers control visibility: (1) public - accessible from anywhere, (2) private - only within the same class, (3) protected - within the same class, subclasses, and same package, (4) (default/package-private) - within same package. Best practice: fields private, methods public, except internal helpers.
